text: [Music]
hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with flaxseed crackers that's right
meet the flack errs which by the way is
what i really would have loved to call
these except someone had already
registered that name which was
unfortunate but good for them but anyway
names aside
when i found out you could turn this
superfood into crispy delicious crackers
basically just by adding water i decided
to give it a try
and was very happy with the results so
with that let's go ahead and get started
by adding some flax seeds to bowl and
i'm using the brown variety here but
they also come in a lighter golden
version and either one will work here
and while these seeds and some water are
the only mandatory ingredients we should
probably also add a little bit of
seasoning which i'm going to do with
some salt although i hear some people
use soy sauce and i might try that next
time i'm also gonna add a little bit of
garlic powder as well as some onion
powder and then we'll also go ahead and
add a few shakes of cayenne just to stay
in shape and then last but not least we
will add the same amount of cold fresh
water as we added seeds ok so equal
parts flax seeds and water and believe
it or not that's it all we need to do is
take a fork and give this a mix at which
point we're gonna wrap this up and then
transfer it into the fridge overnight so
the seeds can fully hydrate and i've
heard you can get away with just soaking
these for a few hours but i've also
heard that overnight is better so as
with most things that's gonna be up to
you you guys are after all the Lou
Reed's of how long to soak your seeds
but I did wrap mine up and pop them in
the fridge overnight and then pulled
them out the next morning at which point
they'll look like this and as you can
see all that water's been absorbed and
the seeds have taken on a very very
interesting texture they've gotten very
thick and stiff yet the mixture is still
pliable and they feel like something's
sort of halfway between sticky and slimy
which is good because that's what's
gonna hold these crackers together so
what we'll do is go ahead and transfer
that onto a lined baking sheet and as
you can see I'm using a Silpat but I
hear parchment paper will also work and
what we'll do you see some sort of
spatula is spread this out to about an
eighth of an inch thick
which is gonna be maybe about three
seeds deep in case that helps and as we
spread this we want to try to get it as
even as possible which thanks to this
truly unique texture is actually pretty
easy and I guess if you want you could
put a piece of plastic wrap over this
and sort of press it down but I went
freestyle and it worked out pretty well
and while you can spread this a little
bit thicker be careful not to go too
thin because they might end up a little
too fragile once they're crisp alright I
want these things sturdy enough to be
able to stand up to all your basic
spreads and dips so I went ahead and
spread that out as shown and then went
around with a spatula and sort of evened
up the edges which I'm guessing is
unnecessary but I did it anyway and then
if we want we could just bake this as is
and then once done sort of break it up
into irregular pieces but I'm actually
gonna take this bench scraper and go
ahead and score this into thirty-two
squares where I guess technically
rectangles if that's the kind of thing
that would bother you and that way once
these are crisp and cooled we can break
them up into some regularly sized
portions and that's it once that set
these are ready to bake if you can even
call it that since we're gonna transfer
this into the center of a very low 200
degree oven for about three hours or so
or until our crackers are crisp but what
I did after the one hour mark since I
noticed my lines were disappearing as I
pulled him out and reestablished those
brake lines and while it was sort of
firming up a little bit and sort of
starting to get crisp I could tell us
still had a ways to go so I popped it
back in for a total of about three hours
at which point they look like this they
had sort of darkened up and apparently
contracted a little because I could see
that sill pad is sort of buckled up here
and there and while I thought these did
feel crispy I went ahead and test it
anyway since fork dough live
oh yeah and that's it all we have to do
is wait for these to cool which I'm
gonna recommend we do in the turned off
oven with the door slightly cracked
which I think will help make sure these
are fully dehydrated and that's it once
these were totally cool we can go ahead
and break them up which should be pretty
easy if we scored these ahead of time
and like I said if you don't you could
just break these into regular pieces
which who knows might even look cooler
and then once we have these successfully
separated they're ready to enjoy anyway
you'd enjoy a regular cracker which for
me this time was going to be with a thin
slice of farmhouse cheddar and not only
are these crackers super light and very
crisp they also taste pretty good which
is not always the case with super food
substitutes I'm looking at you quinoa
but anyway above and beyond the
fantastic texture these really are
delicious so I decided to have one more
only this time I decide to upgrade my
cheese with some membrillo
which is a quince paste which is sort of
sweet and tart and makes for an
absolutely perfect pairing with that
earthy nutty cracker but anyway that's
it the very simple and easy technique
for making your own flaxseed crackers or
as I wish I could call them flowers and
besides the amazing texture and great
taste from what I hear flax seeds are
one of the most nutritious things you
could possibly eat so besides making up
an interesting snack we can also get a
head start on those New Year's
resolutions you know the ones like eat
less processed carbs and more birdseed
so for all those reasons and more I
really do hope you give these a try soon
so hetero to food wishes calm for all
the ingredient amounts and more info as
usual and as always enjoy
you
you
